text:
Thank you for subscribing!   
If one of your New Year resolutions was to give the old grey matter a work-out, treat the following as a gymnasium for the mind. 
Listed here are just some of the lectures – the vast majority free – which are open to the North East public in the coming weeks. 
University lecturers and professors are not, it seems, in the business of saving their expert knowledge exclusively for students. 
Through these public lecture series we are all welcome to benefit from their great learning and insight. 
But not all the lectures offered by the following educational establishments – plus the venerable Literary and Philosophical Society of Newcastle upon Tyne (Lit & Phil) – are to be delivered by university academics. 
Speakers also include gay rights campaigner Peter Tatchell; Mike Brown, head of the National Bee Unit; Dr Nicholas Cullinan, director of the National Portrait Gallery; Steve Cram, the BBC’s chief athletics correspondent; and crime writer Ann Cleeves. UNIVERSITY OF DURHAM... Prof Timothy Garton Ash: Free Speech Under Attack 
Wednesday, February 8, 8pm 
Prof Ash, of the University of Oxford, is the author of nine books charting the transformation of Europe over the past 30 years. 
In his lecture he will look at what can be done to defend free speech when “from Turkey to Russia, in Egypt, China, Poland and now in the United States”, it is under attack. 
* This Durham Castle Lecture takes place in the Great Hall, Durham Castle. Doors open at 7.30pm and seats are allocated on a first come, first served basis. No ticket required. For the full list of public lectures at University of Durham go to www.dur.ac.uk/whatson/lectures_seminars/ NEWCASTLE UNIVERSITY... Prof Bill Fraser: Give me sunshine 
Wednesday, February 8, 5.30pm 
Last summer Public Health England advised the Government that everyone needed the equivalent of 10 micrograms of Vitamin D daily to protect bone and muscle health. Vitamin D is produced by the skin in response to sunlight. The speaker, professor of medicine at the University of East Anglia, will discuss the role of this important vitamin. Peter Tatchell: 1967 and LGBT liberation 
Tuesday, February 14, 5.30pm 
Fifty years have passed since Parliament passed the Sexual Offences Act, which offered partial decriminalisation of male homosexuality while leaving anti-LGBT laws on the statute book. The high profile human rights campaigner will highlight the iniquities of the system. Rev Jeffrey L Brown: The Courage to Listen 
Tuesday, February 21, 5.30pm 
The speaker, in this Freedom City 2017 Lecture, is a Baptist minister and president of RECAP (Rebuilding Every Community Around Peace), an organisation he established after bringing communities together to reduce gang violence in his home city of Boston, USA. With a book coming out, he will show how to bring people together in conflicted times. Prof Catherine Merridale: Lenin on the Train 
Tuesday, February 28, 5.30pm 
In April 1917, with the First World War raging, the leader of the Russian Bolsheviks took a train from his place of exile in Zurich to Petrograd, the revolutionary Russian capital. As the centenary approaches, the writer and historian recalls “the most momentous train journey in history”. Prof Stephen Graham: The City from Satellites to Bunkers 
Thursday, March 2, 5.30pm 
The speaker, professor of cities and society at Newcastle, explores today’s geography from a vertical perspective as humans excavate deep into the earth and build ever higher into the sky. What does it all say about power and inequality? Mike Brown: Technologies for bee health 
Tuesday, March 7, 5.30pm 
Mike Brown is head of the Animal and Plant Health Agency’s National Bee Unit which delivers the Government’s Healthy Bees Plan. He will discuss the unit’s work and its importance. Vera Baird QC and Kannez Shaid: Citizenship and Equality 
Thursday, March 9, 5.30pm 
The Crime and Police Commissioner for Northumbria and the Chair of the Trustees of Citizens UK will have a conversation, providing insights into community alliances aimed at creating a sense of fairness and a platform for empowering marginalised voices. Chi Onwurah MP: Race to the top – productivity, investment and industrial strategy in the post-Brexit world Newcastle Central MP Chi Onwurah 
Thursday, March 16, 5.30pm 
The Newcastle Central MP and shadow minister for industrial strategy, science and innovation will deliver the RW Mann Lecture, looking at industry in the years ahead. Prof Leon Feinstein: What is the relationship between genetics and social mobility? 
Tuesday, March 21, 5.30pm 
The director of evidence, Children’s Commissioner for England, explains why the science of heredity is not in conflict with attempts to address social inequality. Rather, it indicates the remarkable degree to which beliefs and institutions create barriers. Prof Jennifer Richards: Voices and books – a new history of reading 
Thursday, March 23, 5.30pm 
The speaker will explore the importance of the actual voice to reading. She will explain how the recovery of the lost reading voices of the past, as well as the art of listening, can help us to re-imagine the books of the future. 
* All these Newcastle University lectures are part of its Insights programme and free and open to all. They take place in the Curtis Auditorium, Herschel Building, Newcastle University, NE1 7IU. More details at http://www.ncl.ac.uk/events/public-lectures/upcoming/ NORTHUMBRIA UNIVERSITY... Prof Alister Scott: Changing the nature of nature in land use policy and decision making 
Tuesday, February 14, 6.30pm 
Nature has traditionally been seen as an impediment to growth and development – and it is in rapid decline. The speaker, professor of environmental geography, will argue that to stave off environmental collapse there has to be a change in the way we account for nature. Dr Nicholas Cullinan: A Portrait Gallery for the Nation Dr Nicholas Cullinan, director of the National Portrait Gallery 
Monday, February 27, 6.30pm 
The director of the National Portrait Gallery, visiting Newcastle as the gallery’s self-portrait by Sir Anthony Van Dyck is on show at the Laing Art Gallery, will talk about the role of portraits and of his own gallery in contemporary British society. Prof Michael Jopling: Is there a North-South divide among schools in England? 
Monday, March 13, 6.30pm 
In the lecture, Northumbria’s professor of education will challenge prevalent characterisations of ‘successful’ and ‘failing’ schools and suggest we need to find better and more sensitive ways to assess the way schools respond to complex challenges. Prof Becky Strachan: Let’s Educate, Learn and Flourish 
Wednesday, April 5, 6.30pm 
Northumbria’s professor of digital technology and education will explore the current educational landscape and argue that educators need to be more adventurous. She will show how we should reimagine education and use technology in transformational ways 
* All these Northumbria University lectures are free and open to all. They take place in the Presentation Hall, Design Building, City Campus East, NE1 2SW with refreshments available from 6pm. More details at www.northumbria.ac.uk/about-us/news-events/public-lecture/ UNIVERSITY OF SUNDERLAND... Steve Cram and Jonathon Riall Steve Cram, Chancellor of the University of Sunderland 
Wednesday, February 8, 6.30pm 
Was 2016 a good or bad year for sport? It saw a huge GB medal haul at the Rio Olympic and Paralympic Games but also allegations of bribery, corruption and doping. 
In a lecture – perhaps more of a discussion – chaired by Jeff Brown of BBC Look North, the speakers will argue that highs outweighed lows. 
Cram is the BBC’s chief athletics commentator and Chancellor of the University of Sunderland. Riall, a Sunderland graduate, is Team GB’s head coach for the paratriathlon team which competed for the first time in Rio. Dominic Wilcox 
Wednesday, March 8, 6.30pm 
The Sunderland-born artist and designer specialises in innovative and thought-provoking projects and has been commissioned by the likes of Paul Smith, Selfridges, BMW Mini and Jaffa Cakes. 
He has said: “I’ve convinced myself that within everything that surrounds us, there are hundreds of ideas and connections waiting to be found. We just need to look hard enough.” 
In his lecture he promises a high speed journey through his creative life so far. 
* These free lectures take place at the Sir Tom Cowie Lecture Theatre, Prospect Building, St Peter’s Campus, Sunderland SR6 0DD. Tickets and details at www.sunderland.ac.uk/public-lecture-series/ NEWCASTLE COLLEGE... Dr Tiffany Jenkins: Keeping their Marbles 
Thursday, February 9, 6pm 
Dr Jenkins is an author, writer and broadcaster. Her book Keeping Their Marbles: How Treasures of the Past Ended Up in Museums and Why They Should Stay There, touching on the long-running controversy of the Elgin Marbles (taken from Greek sites such as the Parthenon in the early 19th Century and installed at the British Museum), came out last year to critical acclaim. Dr Christopher Davidson: Shadow Wars – The Secret Struggles of the Middle East Dr Christopher Davidson 
Thursday, March 2, 6pm 
The Durham University academic is a Middle East expert who was previously an assistant professor at Zayed University in the United Arab Emirates. 
Shadow Wars is the latest of his books. Meticulously researched, it looks at the reality behind the brief euphoria of the Arab Spring of 2011. A glimpse at www.goodreads.com will tell you it was well received. Dr Andrew McGettigan: Whatever happened to the Polytechnics? 
Thursday, April 6, 6pm 
The speaker writes about higher education, contributes to a blog called Critical Education and is the author of a book called The Great University Gamble: Money, Markets and the Future of Higher Education. Prof Peter Wadhams: The Arctic and Global Climate Change 
Thursday, May 11, 6pm 
The Cambridge University oceanographer and glaciologist leads a group studying the effects of global warming on sea ice, icebergs and the polar oceans. 
This involves work in the Arctic and Antarctic from nuclear subs, autonomous underwater vehicles, icebreakers, aircraft and drifting ice camps. 
His latest book, chillingly, is called A Farewell to Ice. Prof Kate Gould: Antibiotics from Prehistory to the Present Day Prof Kate Gould 
Thursday, June 8, 6pm 
Prof Gould is lead public health microbiologist for Public Health England and honorary consultant microbiologist at Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust. 
Her lecture will focus on the crisis of global antibiotic resistance. 
* These Newcastle College free lectures all take place at partner organisation the Lit & Phil, 23 Westgate Road, Newcastle NE1 1SE. Book at www.litandphil.org.uk LIT & PHIL... Ann Cleeves and Emma Flint Vera author Ann Cleeves (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
Thursday, February 9, 7pm 
Ann Cleeves, creator of Vera and author of 30 novels, will discuss her latest, Cold Earth, with Gail-Nina Anderson and the pair will be joined by Emma Flint, who grew up in Newcastle and whose debut novel, Little Deaths, has been creating a buzz. Read More Gail-Nina Anderson: John William Waterhouse 
Monday, February 13, 6pm (£3) 
Newcastle-based cultural historian Gail-Nina Anderson specialises in art and this is one in her series of lectures about artists who died in 1917. 
In a year when the horrors of the First World War claimed many young lives, this Victorian artist who specialised in a “dream-world of nymphs and damsels” quietly breathed his last. Alistair McCleery: What are Writers Worth? 
Monday, February 20, 6pm (£3) 
The speaker is director of the Scottish Centre for the Book at Edinburgh Napier University. 
He will offer an insight into the earnings of authors, the economics of self-publishing and writing as a career in 2017. Read More Prof Alan Watson: Searching for the highest-energy particles in nature 
Tuesday, March 7, 6pm 
The speaker, from the School of Physics and Astronomy at University of Leeds, will outline the history behind the discovery of cosmic rays and explain the importance of high-energy particles. He is an expert on the Pierre Auger Observatory in Argentina, the largest cosmic ray detector ever built which covers an area the size of West Yorkshire. David Hughes: Jeremiah Dixon 
Thursday, February 23, 6pm 
Dixon is largely remembered for his part in surveying the Mason-Dixon line in the United States, settling an 18th Century boundary dispute between the then British colonies of Maryland, Delaware and Pennsylvania. 
But Dixon, born in Cockfield, County Durham, was also an astronomer who travelled widely in an effort to determine the scale of the solar system and the size and shape of Earth. 
* These lectures all take place at the Lit & Phil, 23 Westgate Road, Newcastle NE1 1SE. Book at www.litandphil.org.uk Like us on Facebook
